Git & Version Control

What is Version Control?

Version control is a system that records changes to a file or set of files over time so that you can recall specific versions later. If you are a graphic or web designer and want to keep every version of an image or layout (which you would most certainly want to), a Version Control System (VCS) is a very wise thing to use. It allows you to revert selected files back to a previous state, revert the entire project back to a previous state, compare changes over time, see who last modified something that might be causing a problem, who introduced an issue and when, and more.

Git

Git is a distributed version control system that enables software development teams to have multiple local copies of the project's codebase independent of each other. These copies, or branches, can be created, merged, and deleted quickly.

SSH Key

SSH keys are a way to identify trusted computers without requiring passwords. An SSH key is necessary for secure connections to Git repositories, especially when using services like GitHub or Bitbucket.

GitHub

GitHub is a platform for version control and collaboration. It lets you and others work together on projects from anywhere. GitHub integrates with Git, providing a graphical interface and additional project management tools.

Collaboration via Git Connection

Collaborating through Git involves managing branches, handling merge conflicts, and sharing changes through push and pull commands. Effective collaboration often requires additional Git tools and strategies like pull requests and code reviews.

Terminal Commands

Using Git effectively requires familiarity with the terminal. Common commands include 'git clone', 'git pull', 'git push', 'git branch', and 'git checkout'. Mastery of these commands is essential for managing and navigating repositories.
